contextId.information: The Israelites worshiping the Canaanite gods is spoken of as if the false gods were a hunter's trap that catches an animal and causes it harm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: their gods will become a trap for you

contextId.information: The Israelites starting to worship false gods is spoken of as if the Israelites walked and went after the false gods. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They went after other gods

contextId.information: The anger of Yahweh is described as burning like a fire. AT: "Yahweh became very angry with the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The anger of Yahweh burned against Israel

contextId.information: Yahweh allowing the enemies to take the Israelites as slaves is spoken of as if he sold them into slavery. The phrase "who were held by" can be stated in active form. AT: "He allowed their enemies to conquer them and take them as slaves, and they could no longer resist their powerful enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: He sold them as slaves who were held by the strength of their enemies around them, so they could no longer defend themselves against their enemies

contextId.information: Yahweh appointing persons to be judges is spoken of as if he were raising or lifting the persons up. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Then Yahweh raised up judges

contextId.information: Yahweh appointing persons to be judges is spoken of as if he raised or lifted up the persons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When Yahweh raised up judges

contextId.information: The Israelites worshiping other gods is spoken of as if they were walking and going after other gods. AT: "They would serve and worship other gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They would go after other gods to serve them and worship them

contextId.information: Yahweh becoming very angry is spoken of as if his anger were something that could be set on fire. AT: "Yahweh became very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the anger of Yahweh was set on fire

contextId.information: Yahweh appointing someone to do a special work for him is spoken of as if Yahweh raised or lifted up the person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh raised up someone

contextId.information: Yahweh appointing someone to do a special service for him is spoken of as if he raised or lifted up the person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: raised up someone

contextId.information: Yahweh helping the Israelites to defeat their enemies is spoken of as if Yahweh were a warrior who would fight and defeat their enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for Yahweh is about to defeat your enemies

contextId.information: The choice Barak makes is spoken of as if Barak were choosing a road on which to travel. And, "honor" is spoken of as if it were a destination to which one travels. AT: "no one will honor you for what you do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the road on which you are going will not lead to your honor

contextId.information: Like a person in a deep hole cannot easily climb out, a person in a deep sleep cannot easily wake up. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a deep sleep

contextId.information: God causing the Israelites to defeat Jabin and his army is spoken of as is God himself defeated Jabin as the people of Israel watched. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God defeated Jabin, the king of Canaan, before the people of Israel

contextId.information: This speaks of Deborah's leadership as if she were the mother of the Israelites. AT: "I took care of the Israelites like a mother takes care of her children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a mother took command in Israel

contextId.information: The people of Ephraim living in the land where the descendants of Amalek originally lived is spoken of as if the people of Ephraim were planted and their roots grew into the land. AT: "from Ephraim, that land where the descendants of Amalek once lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: from Ephraim, whose root is in Amalek

contextId.information: Moses speaks of Egypt as if it were a house where people keep slaves. AT: "the place where you were slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the house of slavery

contextId.information: This speaks of worshiping a false god as if it were prostitution. AT: "the Israelites sinned against Yahweh by worshiping the ephod there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: all Israel prostituted themselves by worshiping it there

contextId.information: This speaks of Gideon and his family being tempted to worship the ephod as if the ephod were a hunter's snare that would trap them. AT: "It became a temptation for Gideon and his family" or "Gideon and his family sinned by worshiping it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: It became a trap for Gideon and for those in his house

contextId.information: The people rejecting Yahweh is spoken of as if they physically turned away from him. AT: "they stopped worshiping Yahwheh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turned again

contextId.information: Jotham is speaking a curse. He speaks of the people of Shechem and Beth Millo destroying Abimelech as if they would burn him with fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let fire come out from the men of Shechem and Beth Millo, to burn up Abimelech

contextId.information: This speaks of evil as if it were an object that a person could add to and make bigger. AT: "continued doing what Yahweh said was evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: added to the evil they had done in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: Yahweh becoming angry is spoken of as if anger were a burning fire. AT: "Yahweh was very angry at Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh burned with anger toward Israel

contextId.information: The people no longer obeying and worshiping Yahweh is spoken of as if they left Yahweh and went somewhere else. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you abandoned me again

contextId.information: Here Jephthah speaks of his great sorrow as something that crushes him. AT: "You have caused me great sorrow" or "You have filled me with sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You have crushed me with sorrow

contextId.information: Something that Yahweh has stated is unfit to eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:13:06|13:7]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that the law declares to be unclean

contextId.information: Here the way Yahweh's Spirit influences Samson is compared to the way a spoon stirs food in a pot. AT: "Yahweh's Spirit began to influence Samson" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh's Spirit began to stir him

contextId.information: Here figuring out the answer to the riddle is spoke of as if it were something hidden that the guest had to search for and find. AT: "could not figure out the answer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: could not find the answer

contextId.information: Here the author speak of Samson being under the rulers' control as if he were something grasped tightly by their hands. AT: "put him under our control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: put him in our grasp

contextId.information: Here the man looked up and paid attention to what was around him. AT: "He looked up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He raised his eyes

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of "agreeing" as if it were "listening." AT: "the men would not accept his offer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the men would not listen to him

contextId.information: The completed destruction of the Benjamites is spoken of as if the Israelites stomped on their bodies. AT: "they completely destroyed them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and trampled them down

contextId.information: The destruction of the tribe of Benjamin is spoken of as if it had been cut off from Israel by a knife. AT: "one tribe has been removed." This was an exaggeration because 600 men were still left. However, the Benjamin women had been killed, so the future of the tribe was in question. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: one tribe has been cut off from Israel
